properties.name: <![CDATA[Ilford Rd Metro Station NZ 2499 6732]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Exit from the northbound platform and turn left (South) to nearby road bridge over railway line.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Exit from the northbound platform and turn left (South) to nearby road bridge over railway line.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Town Moor View (NZ 2494 6721)]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Pause on bridge to look across allotments to the busy Great North Rd - ancient route to Holy Island and beyond.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Pause on bridge to look across allotments to the busy Great North Rd - ancient route to Holy Island and beyond.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Jesmond Dene Rd junction NZ 2507 6718]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Cross the main road carefully at this junction!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Cross the main road carefully at this junction!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[La Sagesse NZ 2523 6720]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The new buildings at Friday Fields Lane are in grounds of  former convent school called, appropriately, "La Sagesse."  Alumna include actress Denise Welch and poet, Gillian Alnutt.  It was also used as a film location for  CBBC's Tracey Beaker series.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The new buildings at Friday Fields Lane are in grounds of  former convent school called, appropriately, "La Sagesse."  Alumna include actress Denise Welch and poet, Gillian Alnutt.  It was also used as a film location for  CBBC's Tracey Beaker series.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Entering the Dene]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[For a step and hill-free alterative to this section of the route just keep on the road.  The route will meet up with you again shortly.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[For a step and hill-free alterative to this section of the route just keep on the road.  The route will meet up with you again shortly.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Jesmond Dene]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[In the 1850's the wealthy Tyneside industrialist, inventor and  armaments manufacturer William Armstrong bought this valley with the Ouseburn running through it, to develop as private parkland for his Newcastle home.   Together with his wife Margaret - a keen horticulturalist - he re-designed the landscape.  He allowed the public to visit twice a week, on the payment of a small fee, which went to support the local hospital.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[In the 1850's the wealthy Tyneside industrialist, inventor and  armaments manufacturer William Armstrong bought this valley with the Ouseburn running through it, to develop as private parkland for his Newcastle home.   Together with his wife Margaret - a keen horticulturalist - he re-designed the landscape.  He allowed the public to visit twice a week, on the payment of a small fee, which went to support the local hospital.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Grotto]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[This was created from an old quarry as a place of mystery and quiet contemplation. Go carefully down the steps on your left if you want to explore - but go carefully.  It can be very muddy!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This was created from an old quarry as a place of mystery and quiet contemplation. Go carefully down the steps on your left if you want to explore - but go carefully.  It can be very muddy!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Waterfall]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Entirely artificial, this is nevertheless a beautiful example of human and natural forces combined. Sir William Armstrong was fascinated by the power of water.  His country home at Cragside (now a National Trust property) was the first to be lit by hydro-electricity.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Entirely artificial, this is nevertheless a beautiful example of human and natural forces combined. Sir William Armstrong was fascinated by the power of water.  His country home at Cragside (now a National Trust property) was the first to be lit by hydro-electricity.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Riverside Path]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Continue on the path nearest to the river, without crossing it.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Continue on the path nearest to the river, without crossing it.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[A Hive of Industry]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The Ouseburn, in times gone by was lined with watermills, grinding corn from the local farms, and later on all kinds of industry which relied on the water for power, or to wash away waste products.  It's hard to imagine now!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The Ouseburn, in times gone by was lined with watermills, grinding corn from the local farms, and later on all kinds of industry which relied on the water for power, or to wash away waste products.  It's hard to imagine now!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[A Right to Roam...]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[In 1883, Lord Armstrong gifted Jesmond Dene to the Corporation of Newcastle for the benefit of the people.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[In 1883, Lord Armstrong gifted Jesmond Dene to the Corporation of Newcastle for the benefit of the people.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Crossing the Stream]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Cross when you reach the point where the path doubles back up the hill, and there are two bridges.You may see waymark signs here for the "Northern Saints' Trail" - one of our sister long-distance pilgrimage routes.  And don't be thrown by the fingerposts, which are sometimes facing the wrong way!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Cross when you reach the point where the path doubles back up the hill, and there are two bridges.You may see waymark signs here for the "Northern Saints' Trail" - one of our sister long-distance pilgrimage routes.  And don't be thrown by the fingerposts, which are sometimes facing the wrong way!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Waterfalls, weirs and wildlife]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Look out for dippers, goosander and wagtails down here!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Look out for dippers, goosander and wagtails down here!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Red Walk]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[...for obvious reasons.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[...for obvious reasons.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Take the High Road]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Turn up the slope here - or continue along the Red Walk and then climb the steep steps hidden round the foot of the high bridge.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Turn up the slope here - or continue along the Red Walk and then climb the steep steps hidden round the foot of the high bridge.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Over the High Bridge]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Up the Hill]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Sharp left here and around the bottom of the derelict Banquetting Hall.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Sharp left here and around the bottom of the derelict Banquetting Hall.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Historic Trees]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[In 1884, the Prince and Princess of Wales planted a "Turkey Oak" here to mark the opening of Jesmond Dene as a public park.  Nearby is also a Horse Chestnut said to have been grown from a conker brought back by a soldier from the Belgian front in World War 1.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[In 1884, the Prince and Princess of Wales planted a "Turkey Oak" here to mark the opening of Jesmond Dene as a public park.  Nearby is also a Horse Chestnut said to have been grown from a conker brought back by a soldier from the Belgian front in World War 1.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Under the Road]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[If you have reached this point by going along the road, continue to "The Grove" and go right and right again to St Mary's Chapel. (Waymark 22)]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[If you have reached this point by going along the road, continue to "The Grove" and go right and right again to St Mary's Chapel. (Waymark 22)]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA["Jesus Mount"]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The name "Jesmond" is derived from "Jesus' Mount" - and in medieval times pilgrims would flock to Newcastle to climb up from the River Tyne and walk the pilgrim route to visit this holy spot.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The name "Jesmond" is derived from "Jesus' Mount" - and in medieval times pilgrims would flock to Newcastle to climb up from the River Tyne and walk the pilgrim route to visit this holy spot.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Mary's Chapel]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Shortly after the Norman Conquest, it is said that an apparition took place, of Mary and the Christ child in the Dene. Over the next 200 years, St Mary's Chapel was built and then extended, as thousands flocked to visit the shrine.  In 1479, a priest from Yorkshire described this place as "one of the greatest in the kingdom, ranking alongside Canterbury and St Paul's Cathedral!It is still used for worship - and candles and gift offerings can often be seen in the niches of the ruins.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Shortly after the Norman Conquest, it is said that an apparition took place, of Mary and the Christ child in the Dene. Over the next 200 years, St Mary's Chapel was built and then extended, as thousands flocked to visit the shrine.  In 1479, a priest from Yorkshire described this place as "one of the greatest in the kingdom, ranking alongside Canterbury and St Paul's Cathedral!It is still used for worship - and candles and gift offerings can often be seen in the niches of the ruins.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Up the Green Lane]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Back on the Grove, turn right up the narrow lane to reach the Holy Well.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Back on the Grove, turn right up the narrow lane to reach the Holy Well.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Holy Well]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Go cautiously if it is wet under foot, as the steps down to the well can be slippery.  Almost certainly what you see now is an 18th Century construction around what is a much older water source.  You can gather the water with a small metal ladle.  Again, this is clearly a place where people still come to offer prayers for healing and God's guidance, as you will see from the statues, prayer requests and ornaments laid around.  The word "GRATIA" (grace) is inscribed above the well mouth.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Go cautiously if it is wet under foot, as the steps down to the well can be slippery.  Almost certainly what you see now is an 18th Century construction around what is a much older water source.  You can gather the water with a small metal ladle.  Again, this is clearly a place where people still come to offer prayers for healing and God's guidance, as you will see from the statues, prayer requests and ornaments laid around.  The word "GRATIA" (grace) is inscribed above the well mouth.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[...and back to the road]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Waypoint no: 25]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This is waypoint no: 25]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Armstrong Bridge]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Worth a short detour for the doves and the views, the elegant Armstrong Bridge was another gift of Lord Armstrong - made of lattice girders and 550 feet in length.A weekend market often takes place on the bridge.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Worth a short detour for the doves and the views, the elegant Armstrong Bridge was another gift of Lord Armstrong - made of lattice girders and 550 feet in length.A weekend market often takes place on the bridge.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Watering Hole]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Plenty of cafes, delis and a pub near here if you're ready for a break.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Plenty of cafes, delis and a pub near here if you're ready for a break.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Careful Crossing...]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Waypoint no: 28]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This is waypoint no: 28]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Jesmond Old Cemetery]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[You could spend hours exploring in here!  Just be aware that in winter the gates are locked at 3.45pm!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[You could spend hours exploring in here!  Just be aware that in winter the gates are locked at 3.45pm!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Pedestrian Crossing]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Cross here - it's tricky later if you don't!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Cross here - it's tricky later if you don't!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Sandyford Stone Brewery]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[This handsome stone building was Robert Deuchar's brewery HQ till 1961.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This handsome stone building was Robert Deuchar's brewery HQ till 1961.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Robert Deuchar's Brewery]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Deuchar was a Scot who moved to Newcastle in the 1860s and made his fortune in property development and beer.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Deuchar was a Scot who moved to Newcastle in the 1860s and made his fortune in property development and beer.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Andrews Kirk]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[There's been a Church of Scotland presence in Newcastle for over 300 yrs.  Lovely community garden here!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[There's been a Church of Scotland presence in Newcastle for over 300 yrs.  Lovely community garden here!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Lambert's Leap]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The stone by the bus-stop marks the site of a narrow escape!  Legend has it that in 1759, young Lambert's horse was startled and leapt over what was then the parapet of a bridge over a steep gorge crossing the (now culverted) burn below.  Miraculously, Lambert somehow got caught in the branches of a tree, which broke his fall and he survived.  His horse, sadly, did not.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The stone by the bus-stop marks the site of a narrow escape!  Legend has it that in 1759, young Lambert's horse was startled and leapt over what was then the parapet of a bridge over a steep gorge crossing the (now culverted) burn below.  Miraculously, Lambert somehow got caught in the branches of a tree, which broke his fall and he survived.  His horse, sadly, did not.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Pilgrimage of Progress]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[1960s tower blocks loom over a pretty Victorian terrace, while the glass & steel of Northumbria University glint in the distance!  What a sight of contrasts!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[1960s tower blocks loom over a pretty Victorian terrace, while the glass & steel of Northumbria University glint in the distance!  What a sight of contrasts!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Sheildfield Green turn-off]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Immediately before the block of garages, take the narrow lane on the left, through to the Green.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Immediately before the block of garages, take the narrow lane on the left, through to the Green.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Poetry and Putting]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[In the same house near here King Charles I was kept under arrest (1646-7) and local poet Robert Gilchrist died in 1844.King Charles is said to have played golf here on Shieldfield Green while he was under house arrest.  The beautiful timbered Tudor house survived until the 1960s.  Its replacement with the King Charles Tower block of flats hardly seems a fair exchange!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[In the same house near here King Charles I was kept under arrest (1646-7) and local poet Robert Gilchrist died in 1844.King Charles is said to have played golf here on Shieldfield Green while he was under house arrest.  The beautiful timbered Tudor house survived until the 1960s.  Its replacement with the King Charles Tower block of flats hardly seems a fair exchange!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Christ Church, Shieldfield]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Christ Church serves one of the most deprived parishes in Newcastle.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Christ Church serves one of the most deprived parishes in Newcastle.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Pedestrian Crossing]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Waypoint no: 39]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This is waypoint no: 39]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Lord Armstrong's birthplace]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Progress and poverty live side by side still.  We wonder what Lord Armstrong would have thought?]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Progress and poverty live side by side still.  We wonder what Lord Armstrong would have thought?]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Three Figures]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[by Norwegian sculptor, Nico Widerberg, whose enigmatic statues can be seen across the Northumbria University campus.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[by Norwegian sculptor, Nico Widerberg, whose enigmatic statues can be seen across the Northumbria University campus.]]>

properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Waypoint no: 42]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This is waypoint no: 42]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Five Figures]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[by Norwegian scupltor, Nico Widerberg]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[by Norwegian scupltor, Nico Widerberg]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Brady & Martin Building]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The handsome frontage of a former chemical works.  Brady & Martin made precision surgical instruments in the 1890s.Nicholas Martin had his original offices on Mosley Street right next to the Cathedral, and was a church warden.  A Cornishman from a farming family, who trained as a chemist, he moved north for work, and his Cornish wife, Nanny Martin is commemorated on the Quire Organ Pipes still.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The handsome frontage of a former chemical works.  Brady & Martin made precision surgical instruments in the 1890s.Nicholas Martin had his original offices on Mosley Street right next to the Cathedral, and was a church warden.  A Cornishman from a farming family, who trained as a chemist, he moved north for work, and his Cornish wife, Nanny Martin is commemorated on the Quire Organ Pipes still.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Bookstack]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Sculpted by Fred Watson, then a tutor at Northumbria Polytechnic in 1992 to celebrate its becoming a University.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Sculpted by Fred Watson, then a tutor at Northumbria Polytechnic in 1992 to celebrate its becoming a University.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St James' United Reformed Church]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Waypoint no: 46]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This is waypoint no: 46]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Dame Allan's Schools]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Look up for the statue of Dame Allan, who founded one of the first schools for poor boys - and girls - in the city, in 1705.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Look up for the statue of Dame Allan, who founded one of the first schools for poor boys - and girls - in the city, in 1705.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Burt Hall]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Home to the Northumberland Miners' Union, look out for the statue of a miner on the rooftop!  Thomas Burt (1837 -1922), a miner's son from Backworth, had only 2 years of schooling, and was working in the pit by the age of 10.  He educated himself to become one of the first working class Members of Parliament in Britain.  He campaigned for votes for all - including women.The miner is modelled on a popular painting by Ralph Hedley, an artist and sculptor who did much of the wood-carving in Newcastle Cathedral.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Home to the Northumberland Miners' Union, look out for the statue of a miner on the rooftop!  Thomas Burt (1837 -1922), a miner's son from Backworth, had only 2 years of schooling, and was working in the pit by the age of 10.  He educated himself to become one of the first working class Members of Parliament in Britain.  He campaigned for votes for all - including women.The miner is modelled on a popular painting by Ralph Hedley, an artist and sculptor who did much of the wood-carving in Newcastle Cathedral.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Wall Mural depicting the History of Newcastle]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[On the walls of this high street store, see a range of detailed and stylised images, cast in concrete by Joyce Pallot (1912 - 2004) and Henry Collins (1910 - 1994) Ranging from the Greek sea-god Oceanus to George Stephenson and his engine "Rocket" all illustrate cultural and historical aspects of the City of Newcastle.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[On the walls of this high street store, see a range of detailed and stylised images, cast in concrete by Joyce Pallot (1912 - 2004) and Henry Collins (1910 - 1994) Ranging from the Greek sea-god Oceanus to George Stephenson and his engine "Rocket" all illustrate cultural and historical aspects of the City of Newcastle.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Northumberland Street]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Turn left onto the pedestrian street - but look right first to see St Thomas Church, Haymarket and the Great North Road - the route the original pilgrims might have trodden to Jesus' Mount and beyond to Holy Island.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Turn left onto the pedestrian street - but look right first to see St Thomas Church, Haymarket and the Great North Road - the route the original pilgrims might have trodden to Jesus' Mount and beyond to Holy Island.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Monumental Masonry]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Step aside, between M&S and Eldon Square shopping centre to see stonework from the old Town Hall and YMCA.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Step aside, between M&S and Eldon Square shopping centre to see stonework from the old Town Hall and YMCA.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Orphan House]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Look right for the plaque where John Wesley established only the 2nd Methodist Chapel in England in 1743 -  his "headquarters in the North"]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Look right for the plaque where John Wesley established only the 2nd Methodist Chapel in England in 1743 -  his "headquarters in the North"]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Historical Figures]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Look up to see statues of 1. Thomas Bewick (illustrator of many books.  His workshop was in the precincts of Newcastle Cathedral)2. Harry Hotspur (Sir Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland - so nicknamed because of his eagerness to enter the fray in battle - and made famous by William Shakespeare.)3. Sir John Marlay (17th Century merchant and politician who orchestrated the defence of Newcastle during the English Civil War when the city lay under seige for 7 months.)4.Roger Thornton (Known as Newcastle's "Dick Whittington" Thornton arrived in poverty but rose to become one of the city's richest and most esteemed citizens.  He died in c.1430 and a his brass memorial can be seen in Newcastle Cathedral. )]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Look up to see statues of 1. Thomas Bewick (illustrator of many books.  His workshop was in the precincts of Newcastle Cathedral)2. Harry Hotspur (Sir Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland - so nicknamed because of his eagerness to enter the fray in battle - and made famous by William Shakespeare.)3. Sir John Marlay (17th Century merchant and politician who orchestrated the defence of Newcastle during the English Civil War when the city lay under seige for 7 months.)4.Roger Thornton (Known as Newcastle's "Dick Whittington" Thornton arrived in poverty but rose to become one of the city's richest and most esteemed citizens.  He died in c.1430 and a his brass memorial can be seen in Newcastle Cathedral. )]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Brunswick Methodist Church]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Newcastle's Central Methodist Church, dating from 1820 - and a focus for Christian worship and social outreach in the city centre.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Newcastle's Central Methodist Church, dating from 1820 - and a focus for Christian worship and social outreach in the city centre.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Grey's Monument]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[This "Nelson's column" of the north commemorates  local man, Charles, Earl Grey - a reforming Prime Minister of the 1830's who was involved in the abolition of the slave trade, and after whom the famous tea was named.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This "Nelson's column" of the north commemorates  local man, Charles, Earl Grey - a reforming Prime Minister of the 1830's who was involved in the abolition of the slave trade, and after whom the famous tea was named.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Grey Street]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Admire the neo-classical curve of Grey Street, designed, as was much of this part of town, by Richard Grainger in the 1830s.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Admire the neo-classical curve of Grey Street, designed, as was much of this part of town, by Richard Grainger in the 1830s.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Pilgrim Street]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[From 1830's elegance to 1960's brutalism  - but you are now, at last on the ancient Pilgrim Street! Turn right onto it.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[From 1830's elegance to 1960's brutalism  - but you are now, at last on the ancient Pilgrim Street! Turn right onto it.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Plaque to Joseph Swan]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Cross at the pedestrian crossing and look at the plaque to Joseph Swan, inventor of the incandescent light bulb.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Cross at the pedestrian crossing and look at the plaque to Joseph Swan, inventor of the incandescent light bulb.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Pedestrian Crossing]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Cross again to head down Pilgrim Street towards the river.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Cross again to head down Pilgrim Street towards the river.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Worswick Street]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Named for Fr. James Worswick who founded the first post-reformation Roman Catholic church in the city in Pilgrim Street in 1798.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Named for Fr. James Worswick who founded the first post-reformation Roman Catholic church in the city in Pilgrim Street in 1798.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[St Andrew's Catholic Church]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[A beautiful little church, on a very run down street.  Pop in if it's open!  Look out for some beautiful stained glass, and a striking sculpture by local artist John O'Rourke at the back.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[A beautiful little church, on a very run down street.  Pop in if it's open!  Look out for some beautiful stained glass, and a striking sculpture by local artist John O'Rourke at the back.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Alderman Fenwick's House]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Look across the busy Pilgrim Street for a fine view of Alderman Fenwick's House - built in 1670, and one of the oldest buildings in the City Centre. (Cross for a closer look if you want, but use the underpasses.)  Fenwick was Mayor of Newcastle in 1720.  The building later became a coaching inn, in which Charles Dickens onced stayed.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Look across the busy Pilgrim Street for a fine view of Alderman Fenwick's House - built in 1670, and one of the oldest buildings in the City Centre. (Cross for a closer look if you want, but use the underpasses.)  Fenwick was Mayor of Newcastle in 1720.  The building later became a coaching inn, in which Charles Dickens onced stayed.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Use the Underpass]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Use the underpass to cross over to the centre of the busy "Swan House" roundabout - an icon, for good or ill, of 1960's brutalist architecture, and a legacy of the notorious T. Dan Smith,  Leader of the Council from from 1960 to 1965.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Use the underpass to cross over to the centre of the busy "Swan House" roundabout - an icon, for good or ill, of 1960's brutalist architecture, and a legacy of the notorious T. Dan Smith,  Leader of the Council from from 1960 to 1965.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Swan House Roundabout]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The building of the road and roundabout system here unearthed the remains of a Quaker Cemetery, which had been attached to the Meeting House, in Pilgrim Street since 1698.  The new  luxury flats are called "55 Degrees North" because Newcastle is at that line of latitude.  TV duo Ant and Dec are said to have a residence here!]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The building of the road and roundabout system here unearthed the remains of a Quaker Cemetery, which had been attached to the Meeting House, in Pilgrim Street since 1698.  The new  luxury flats are called "55 Degrees North" because Newcastle is at that line of latitude.  TV duo Ant and Dec are said to have a residence here!]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Articulated Opposites]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Cross the roundabout, towards views of the Tyne Bridge, and you will find an abstract bronze sculpture, designed by Raymond Arnatt (1934 - 2004) in 1969.  Inspired by the shape of early filament light bulbs, the sculpture commemorates the inventor, Sir Joseph Swan whose plaque we saw earlier.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Cross the roundabout, towards views of the Tyne Bridge, and you will find an abstract bronze sculpture, designed by Raymond Arnatt (1934 - 2004) in 1969.  Inspired by the shape of early filament light bulbs, the sculpture commemorates the inventor, Sir Joseph Swan whose plaque we saw earlier.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Holy Jesus Hospital]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Now offices, and the NE headquarters of the National Trust, the building you can see across the road dates from 1681, but was built on the site of a C13th Augustinian Friary, and then later served as an almshouse and a soup kitchen, as you can see from the wall inscription.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Now offices, and the NE headquarters of the National Trust, the building you can see across the road dates from 1681, but was built on the site of a C13th Augustinian Friary, and then later served as an almshouse and a soup kitchen, as you can see from the wall inscription.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Cross at the Pedestrian Crossing]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Waypoint no: 67]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[This is waypoint no: 67]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Let there be Light!]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[You are now walking down Mosley Street, which, on the 3rd of February 1879, was the first public street in the world to be lit by the incandescent light bulb invented by Joseph Swan.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[You are now walking down Mosley Street, which, on the 3rd of February 1879, was the first public street in the world to be lit by the incandescent light bulb invented by Joseph Swan.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Old Town / New Town]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Pause at the crossroads to look up the hill at the neo-classical elegance of Grey Street and downhill to get a feel for the earlier cramped and bustling cityscape of Dean Street - one of the main thoroughfares from the quayside to the city centre.  Under your feet flows the now culverted "Lort Burn" heading down to the river, and the focus of Newcastle's  commerce for many centuries.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[Pause at the crossroads to look up the hill at the neo-classical elegance of Grey Street and downhill to get a feel for the earlier cramped and bustling cityscape of Dean Street - one of the main thoroughfares from the quayside to the city centre.  Under your feet flows the now culverted "Lort Burn" heading down to the river, and the focus of Newcastle's  commerce for many centuries.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Old Theatre Royal]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[The narrow and non-descript alleyway across the road here is Drury Lane - the only remaining evidence that the glittering magic and limelight of Newcastle's first Theatre Royal once stood there.]]>
properties.desc: <![CDATA[The narrow and non-descript alleyway across the road here is Drury Lane - the only remaining evidence that the glittering magic and limelight of Newcastle's first Theatre Royal once stood there.]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[Statue of Queen Victoria]]>

properties.name: <![CDATA[The Great West Doors of Newcastle Cathedral]]>
properties.cmt: <![CDATA[Welcome, pilgrim!  Please come in!]]>
